messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

messages.content: "118 :     public static FastDateFormat getInstance(String pattern) {\n119 :         return cache.getInstance(pattern, null, null);\n120 :     }"

messages.name: get_code_snippet
get_code_snippet
get_comments
messages.content:
" *

Formats a {@code Calendar} object.

* * @param calendar the calendar to format * @return the formatted string "

messages.name: get_comments
messages.content:
" *

Gets a formatter instance using the specified pattern in the * default locale.

* * @param pattern {@link java.text.SimpleDateFormat} compatible * pattern * @return a pattern based date/time formatter * @throws IllegalArgumentException if pattern is invalid "

messages.name: get_comments
messages.content:
" *

Constructs a new FastDateFormat.

* * @param pattern {@link java.text.SimpleDateFormat} compatible pattern * @param timeZone non-null time zone to use * @param locale non-null locale to use * @throws NullPointerException if pattern, timeZone, or locale is null. "

Diagnosis:

The failing test `testCalendarTimezoneRespected` is from the class `FastDatePrinterTest` in the package `org.apache.commons.lang3.time`. This test is checking whether the timezone is respected by the `FastDateFormat` class when formatting a `Calendar` object.

The test sets up a `Calendar` object using a `TimeZone` (`anotherZone`) different from the default `TimeZone`. It then creates a `SimpleDateFormat` object (`sdf`) with the specified pattern and the `TimeZone` (`anotherZone`). It formats the `Calendar` object using `sdf` and expects the same result when using `FastDateFormat` to format the `Calendar` object with the same pattern.

However, the test fails with the error: `expected:<5:31PM [IC]T> but was:<5:31PM [PS]T>`. This indicates that the expected and actual formatted values are not matching.

Looking at the code of `FastDateFormat`, we see that when formatting a `Calendar` object, it delegates the formatting to an instance of `FastDatePrinter`. The `FastDateFormat.format(Calendar)` method simply calls the `format` method of the `FastDatePrinter` instance, passing the `Calendar` object as a parameter.

The `FastDateFormat.getInstance(String)` method is used to obtain an instance of `FastDateFormat` with the specified pattern. It internally uses a cache (`FormatCache`) to store and retrieve previously created instances. The `getInstance` method calls `cache.getInstance` to get the instance with the specified pattern.

The `FastDateFormat` class has a nested class named `Anonymous-8374acab-e83a-4f2b-8402-2a476c511507` that extends `FormatCache`. This anonymous class overrides the `createInstance` method, which is responsible for creating a new instance of `FastDateFormat` with the specified pattern, `TimeZone`, and `Locale`.

The `FastDateFormat` constructor initializes the `FastDatePrinter` and `FastDateParser` with the specified pattern, `TimeZone`, and `Locale`.

Based on the code and test failure, it seems that the issue lies in the formatting of the `Calendar` object. The `FastDatePrinter` instance used by `FastDateFormat` is producing a different formatted value compared to the `SimpleDateFormat` with the same pattern and `TimeZone`.

Possible Fix:

The issue could be related to the implementation of the `FastDatePrinter` class, specifically the logic for formatting timezones. One possible fix would be to investigate and modify the code in the `FastDatePrinter` class to ensure consistent formatting of timezones.

Another fix could be to investigate the usage of timezones in the `FastDateFormat` class and ensure that the correct timezone is used for formatting the `Calendar` object.

Suggestions to fix the bug:

org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDatePrinter.format(Calendar)

org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat.getInstance(String)

org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat.Anonymous-8374acab-e83a-4f2b-8402-2a476c511507.createInstance(String, TimeZone, Locale)

org.apache.commons.lang3.time.FastDateFormat.FastDateFormat(String, TimeZone, Locale)

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
